case_title: Jawwad S. Khawaja vs. Federation of Pakistan, etc.
complaint_summary: Petitions challenged the trial of civilians under Pakistan Army Act, 1952, following violent incidents on May 9-10, 2023, arguing violation of fundamental rights including Article 10A (fair trial).
judgment_summary: The Supreme Court declared Sections 2(1)(d) and 59(4) of the Pakistan Army Act unconstitutional, ruling that civilians must be tried in ordinary criminal courts. The Court emphasized the violation of fundamental rights and the lack of procedural safeguards in military courts.
Decision_or_verdict: Sections 2(1)(d) and 59(4) of the Army Act invalidated; civilians to be tried in ordinary courts.
legal_arguments: Article 8(3)(a) exemption applies only to military personnel
Military courts lack independence and procedural safeguards
Precedent in F.B. Ali v. State distinguished due to constitutional evolution post-2010
key_issues: Constitutionality of Sections 2(1)(d) and 59(4) of Army Act
Violation of fundamental rights under Articles 10A, 9, and 25
Jurisdiction of military courts over civilians

legal_terms.Fair Trial: Guarantee under Article 10A ensuring due process and judicial independence.
legal_terms.Military Jurisdiction: Legal authority of military courts, typically limited to armed forces personnel.

words_and_phrases.Constitutional Supremacy: Principle that the Constitution is the highest law of the land.
words_and_phrases.Procedural Safeguards: Legal protections ensuring fairness in judicial proceedings.

summary_vector_notes: The judgment invalidated military court jurisdiction over civilians under Sections 2(1)(d) and 59(4) of the Army Act, reaffirming constitutional guarantees of fair trial and judicial independence. Civilians involved in May 9-10 incidents to be tried in ordinary courts.
